text: Hi, I'm using Franklin to build my professional website.  It's been great so far, but I'm having some trouble running `optimize()`.  Julia doesn't seem aware that `css_html_js_minify` has been installed and throws a warning saying as much.  Has anyone else wrestled with this before?

text:
Hello Jacob! Unfortunately this is an annoying aspect of relying on a python package, we need to specify _which_ python to use... routinely people have a bunch and Julia doesn't know which one to use. Here you use `Conda` but if you used shell mode in Julia and tried to call `python3` does it have access to `css...` ?

Anyway the workaround is to provide explicitly the path to the correct python interpreter, the one that is related to `Conda`  since that's what you use here, you can do that by specifying `ENV["PYTHON3"]` and `ENV["PIP3"]` (see the Franklin build file) then re-building Franklin.

Another approach would be to not use the Conda package and just use the shell mode in Julia (`;` ) do the pip install there, and then it should work. I hope this helps!

That makes total sense.  I knew the problem was along these lines, but my first instinct was to manually set `ENV["CONDA_JL_HOME"]` .  Even though this seems logical, I then ran into new problems actually *activating* the environment within Julia.

Can you tell me what you mean by _*"see the Franklin build file*_" because I suspect something should happen when I run `build Franklin` in *pkg* mode.

Conda seemed to be complicating matters, and so I went the latter route as you pointed out and used shell mode to try and resolve.  However, I must still be missing something.  Can you think of any other obvious trouble-shooting possibilities?

Thank you for all your help!
